quiz.title: Chemistry: Unit 4 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 4.6: Halogens and Noble Gases
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Properties of Group 17 and Group 18 elements

questions.question: Which of the following describes the 'Halogens' (Group 17)?
options: Highly reactive nonmetals with seven valence electrons.
Unreactive gases with a full octet.
Soft metals that react violently with water.
questions.explanation: Halogens need only one more electron to fill their valence shell, making them the most reactive nonmetals.

questions.question: The Noble Gases (Group 18) are known for being 'inert' because:
options: They have a full outer energy level.
They have no electrons at all.
They are located on the far left of the table.
They only exist at absolute zero.
questions.explanation: Having 8 valence electrons (or 2 for Helium) provides maximum stability, so they rarely gain, lose, or share electrons.

questions.question: Which Halogen is a liquid at room temperature?
questions.explanation: Bromine ($Br$) is one of only two elements (along with Mercury) that is liquid at standard room temperature.

questions.question: What is the most electronegative and reactive element in the Halogen group?
questions.explanation: Fluorine ($F$) is the most reactive of all nonmetals because its valence electrons are very close to the nucleus.

questions.question: Which Noble Gas is commonly used in weather balloons and to provide 'lift' because it is less dense than air?
questions.explanation: Helium ($He$) is the second lightest element and is non-flammable, making it safer than Hydrogen for lifting.

questions.question: When Halogens react with metals, they typically form compounds known as:
Which Halogen is added to drinking water and toothpaste to help prevent tooth decay?
questions.explanation: Fluoride ions help strengthen tooth enamel against acid attacks from bacteria.

questions.question: What happens to the physical state of the Halogens as you move down the group from Fluorine to Iodine?
options: They change from gas to liquid to solid.
They change from solid to liquid to gas.
questions.explanation: Fluorine/Chlorine are gases, Bromine is a liquid, and Iodine is a solid due to increasing intermolecular forces.

questions.question: Which Noble Gas is used in high-intensity lamps and as an anesthetic in some medical procedures?
questions.explanation: Xenon ($Xe$) has various specialized uses in lighting and medicine due to its unique properties.

questions.question: Which radioactive Noble Gas can seep into basements from the ground and poses a health risk?
questions.explanation: Radon ($Rn$) is a naturally occurring radioactive gas that can accumulate in enclosed spaces.
